message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Sharing of misinformation is habitual, not just lazy or biased
Paper Abstract: Why do people share misinformation on social media? In this research ( N = 2,476), we show that the structure of online sharing built into social platforms is more important than individual deficits in critical reasoning and partisan bias—commonly cited drivers of misinformation. Due to the reward-based learning systems on social media, users form habits of sharing information that attracts others' attention. Once habits form, information sharing is automatically activated by cues on the platform without users considering response outcomes such as spreading misinformation. As a result of user habits, 30 to 40% of the false news shared in our research was due to the 15% most habitual news sharers. Suggesting that sharing of false news is part of a broader response pattern established by social media platforms, habitual users also shared information that challenged their own political beliefs. Finally, we show that sharing of false news is not an inevitable consequence of user habits: Social media sites could be restructured to build habits to share accurate information.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Habit formation"

Links: [{"title":"Habit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habit"},{"title":"Dynamic unobserved effects model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_unobserved_effects_model"},{"title":"Talk:Child vehicular heat stroke deaths - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Forgotten_baby_syndrome"},{"title":"Crystal habit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_habit"},{"title":"Botryoidal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Botryoidal"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about habit formation:

## Definition and Basics

Habit formation is the process by which a behavior, through regular repetition, becomes automatic or habitual.(no content)Habitual behavior often goes unnoticed by persons exhibiting it, because a person does not need to engage in self-analysis when undertaking routine tasks.

## How Common Habits Are

A 2002 daily experience study by habit researcher Wendy Wood and her colleagues found that approximately 43% of daily behaviors are performed out of habit.

## Timeline for Formation

Research found the average time for participants to reach the asymptote of automaticity was 66 days with a range of 18–254 days.

## Key Components

There are four main components to habit formation: the context cue, craving, behavioral repetition, and the reward. The context cue can be a prior action, time of day, location, or anything that triggers the habitual behavior.(no content)The cue leads to a craving or desire. The craving is the motivational force behind the habit.

## Neural Basis and Difficulty

Old habits are hard to break and new habits are hard to form because the behavioural patterns that humans repeat become imprinted in neural pathways, but it is possible to form new habits through repetition.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "Social media." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Social Media

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn.(no content)These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.

## Major Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.(no content)Other popular platforms that are sometimes referred to as social media services include YouTube, Letterboxd, QQ, Quora, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, LINE, Snapchat, Viber, Reddit, Discord, and TikTok.

## Global Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

## How It Differs from Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Business Applications

In 2014, over 80% of business executives identified social media as an integral part of their business. Business retailers have seen 133% increases in their revenues from social media marketing.

## Concerns

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

I've completed the web search for "Social media." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Social Media

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn.(no content)These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.

## Major Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.(no content)Other popular platforms that are sometimes referred to as social media services include YouTube, Letterboxd, QQ, Quora, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, LINE, Snapchat, Viber, Reddit, Discord, and TikTok.

## Global Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

## How It Differs from Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Business Applications

In 2014, over 80% of business executives identified social media as an integral part of their business. Business retailers have seen 133% increases in their revenues from social media marketing.

## Concerns

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

Web search results for query: "Critical thinking"

Links: [{"title":"Critical Thinking (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_Thinking_(film)"},{"title":"Critical systems thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_systems_thinking"},{"title":"Critical thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_thinking"},{"title":"Paris Institute for Critical Thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris_Institute_for_Critical_Thinking"},{"title":"Inquiry: Critical Thinking Across the Disciplines - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inquiry:_Critical_Thinking_Across_the_Disciplines"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wiki Ed/Wake Tech Community College/HUM 115 Critical Thinking (Fall 2017) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wiki_Ed/Wake_Tech_Community_College/HUM_115_Critical_Thinking_(Fall_2017)"},{"title":"Vertical thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_thinking"},{"title":"Logical reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_reasoning"},{"title":"Fake news - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news"},{"title":"Category:Critical thinking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Critical_thinking"}]

Here's what I found about critical thinking:

## Definition

Critical thinking is the process of analyzing available facts, evidence, observations, and arguments to make sound conclusions or informed choices.(no content)It involves recognizing underlying assumptions, providing justifications for ideas and actions, evaluating these justifications through comparisons with varying perspectives, and assessing their rationality and potential consequences.

## Key Characteristics

The goal of critical thinking is to form a judgment through the application of rational, skeptical, and unbiased analyses and evaluations.(no content)The application of critical thinking includes self-directed, self-disciplined, self-monitored, and self-corrective habits of the mind, as critical thinking is not a natural process; it must be induced, and ownership of the process must be taken for successful questioning and reasoning.

## Historical Background

In the classical period of Ancient Greece, the philosopher Plato indicated that the teachings of Socrates are the earliest records of what today is called critical thinking.(no content)In modern times, the phrase critical thinking was coined by Pragmatist philosopher John Dewey in his book How We Think.

## Learning and Development

According to philosopher Richard W. Paul, critical thinking and analysis are competencies that can be learned or trained.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Partisan bias"

Links: [{"title":"Political bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_bias"},{"title":"Partisan (politics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_(politics)"},{"title":"Nonpartisanship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonpartisanship"},{"title":"Media bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_bias"},{"title":"Criticism of Wikipedia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Criticism_of_Wikipedia"},{"title":"Wikipedia:No. Wikipedia is NOT biased - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No._Wikipedia_is_NOT_biased"},{"title":"NewsNation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewsNation"}]

Here are the search results for "Partisan bias":

## Definition and Overview

Partisan bias exists in the media when reporters serve and create the leaning of a particular political party.(no content)When journalists intentionally or unintentionally show material in a way that prioritizes one political ideology or party over another, they are affecting the public's perception of political events and individuals, with examples including story selection, framing, tone, and the frequency of criticism or support of specific parties or people.

## Effects on Individual Behavior

Partisanship causes survey respondents to answer political surveys differently, even if the survey asks a question with an objective answer, with people with strong partisan beliefs being 12% more likely to give an incorrect answer that benefits their preferred party than an incorrect answer that benefits another party due to the phenomenon of motivated reasoning.

## Media Examples

Empirical research examining over 800,000 news stories from major U.S. broadcasters found significant partisan bias in reporting, with Fox News showing a strong conservative bias, while ABC, CBS, and NBC were shown to have a slight liberal bias.

## Public Perception

According to a Gallup study, 62% of Americans think the media favors one political party, with Republicans majority stating that the media favors Democrats.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Misinformation"

Links: [{"title":"Misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by governments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_governments"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation in the Gaza war - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_in_the_Gaza_war"},{"title":"Vaccine misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_China"},{"title":"5G misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5G_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation about violence by transgender people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_violence_by_transgender_people"},{"title":"Misinformation about the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_the_2024_Atlantic_hurricane_season"},{"title":"Seed oil misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seed_oil_misinformation"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about misinformation:

## Definition and Characteristics

Misinformation is incorrect or misleading information. More specifically, misinformation is information that was originally thought to be true but was later discovered not to be true, and often applies to emerging situations in which there is a lack of verifiable information or changing scientific understanding.(no content)Misinformation can include inaccurate, incomplete, misleading, or false information as well as selective or half-truths.

## Intent and Spread

An important distinction exists between misinformation and similar concepts: whereas misinformation can exist with or without specific malicious intent, disinformation is deliberately deceptive and intentionally propagated. Additionally, misinformation is typically spread unintentionally, mostly caused by a lack of knowledge, an error, or simply a misunderstanding, which contrasts with disinformation.

## Modern Impact

Social media platforms, such as Facebook, Instagram, X, etc., are designed in ways that enable information, including misinformation, to be posted and shared far more quickly than through other communication mediums.(no content)In January 2024, the World Economic Forum identified misinformation and disinformation, propagated by both internal and external interests, to "widen societal and political divides" as the most severe global risks in the short term.(no content)The reason is that misinformation can influence people's beliefs about communities, politics, medicine, and more.

## Historical Context

Misinformation campaigns have existed for hundreds of years. However, the term came into wider recognition during the mid-1990s through the early 2020s, when its effects on public ideological influence began to be investigated.

An important distinction exists between misinformation and similar concepts: whereas misinformation can exist with or without specific malicious intent, disinformation is deliberately deceptive and intentionally propagated. Additionally, misinformation is typically spread unintentionally, mostly caused by a lack of knowledge, an error, or simply a misunderstanding, which contrasts with disinformation.

Social media platforms, such as Facebook, Instagram, X, etc., are designed in ways that enable information, including misinformation, to be posted and shared far more quickly than through other communication mediums.(no content)In January 2024, the World Economic Forum identified misinformation and disinformation, propagated by both internal and external interests, to "widen societal and political divides" as the most severe global risks in the short term.(no content)The reason is that misinformation can influence people's beliefs about communities, politics, medicine, and more.

## Historical Context

Misinformation campaigns have existed for hundreds of years. However, the term came into wider recognition during the mid-1990s through the early 2020s, when its effects on public ideological influence began to be investigated.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about false news and fake news:

## Definition

Fake news or information disorder is false or misleading information (misinformation, disinformation, propaganda, and hoaxes) claiming the aesthetics and legitimacy of news.

## Purpose and Impact

Fake news often has the aim of damaging the reputation of a person or entity, or making money through advertising revenue.(no content)The prevalence of fake news has increased with the recent rise of social media, especially the Facebook News Feed, and this misinformation is gradually seeping into the mainstream media.

## Types of Fake News

In some definitions, fake news includes satirical articles misinterpreted as genuine, and articles that employ sensationalist or clickbait headlines that are not supported in the text.(no content)Fake news websites are those which intentionally, but not necessarily solely, publish hoaxes and disinformation for purposes other than news satire.

## Contributing Factors

Several factors have been implicated in the spread of fake news, such as political polarization, post-truth politics, motivated reasoning, confirmation bias, and social media algorithms.

## Related Terms

Misinformation is information that was originally thought to be true but was later discovered not to be true, and often applies to emerging situations in which there is a lack of verifiable information or changing scientific understanding.

The distinction between these terms is important: misinformation typically refers to false information shared without intent to deceive, while disinformation involves deliberately fabricated information meant to mislead.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Reward learning psychology"

Links: [{"title":"Reward system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_system"},{"title":"Reinforcement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement"},{"title":"Psychology of learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychology_of_learning"},{"title":"Social learning theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_learning_theory"},{"title":"Reward dependence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_dependence"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Motivation crowding theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motivation_crowding_theory"},{"title":"Learning theory (education) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_theories"},{"title":"Kate Wassum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kate_Wassum"},{"title":"Brain stimulation reward - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brain_stimulation_reward"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of reward learning in psychology based on the search results:

## Definition and Basic Concept

Reward is the attractive and motivational property of a stimulus that induces appetitive behavior, also known as approach behavior, and consummatory behavior.(no content)The reward system is a group of neural structures responsible for incentive salience (i.e., "wanting"; desire or craving for a reward and motivation), associative learning (primarily positive reinforcement and classical conditioning), and positively-valenced emotions.

## Historical Development

Ivan Pavlov was a psychologist who used the reward system to study classical conditioning in the late 19th century, rewarding dogs with food after they had heard a bell or another stimulus so that the dogs associated food, the reward, with the bell, the stimulus.(no content)Around the same time, Edward Thorndike used the reward system to study operant conditioning by putting cats in a puzzle box and placing food outside of the box so that the cat wanted to escape.

## Key Psychological Components

Terry Robinson and Kent Berridge's 1993 incentive-sensitization theory proposed that reward contains separable psychological components: wanting (incentive) and liking (pleasure).

## Brain Mechanisms

The ventral tegmental area (VTA) is important in responding to stimuli and cues that indicate a reward is present, triggering the VTA to release dopamine signals to the nucleus accumbens.

## Learning and Motivation

In behaviorism, learning is promoted by positive reinforcement and reiteration.(no content)Various types of motivation play a role, particularly intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, where intrinsic motivation is an inherent type of motivation that one engages as an end to itself, while extrinsic motivation is a motivation that is provided externally such as external awards or punishments.

message_text:
## Task Complete ✅

I have successfully analyzed the paper "Sharing of misinformation is habitual, not just lazy or biased" and completed all required tasks:

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution**
- The paper proposes a novel finding: that misinformation sharing is driven primarily by habitual behavior formed through platform reward structures, rather than individual deficits in reasoning or partisan bias.

**Identified Triples (7 entities):**

1. **Social media** (tool) - Uses: The primary platform where sharing behaviors are reinforced
2. **Misinformation** (concept) - Uses: The core phenomenon being studied
3. **Habit** (concept) - **Proposes**: The paper's main contribution showing habits drive sharing behavior
4. **Reward system** (concept) - Uses: The reward-based mechanisms on platforms that reinforce habits
5. **Political bias** (concept) - Uses: A commonly cited driver that the paper challenges
6. **Critical thinking** (concept) - Uses: Individual reasoning deficits being challenged as the primary cause
7. **Fake news** (concept) - Uses: The specific content type whose sharing patterns are analyzed

**Validation Status:** ✅ **PASSED**
- All Wikipedia URLs verified
- Paper type correctly set to "contribution"
- At least 1 "proposes" relation (required for contribution papers)
- At least 1 "uses" relation (required for all papers)

Sources:
- [Social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media)
- [Misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation)
- [Habit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habit)

- [Political bias](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_bias)

## Task Complete ✅

I have successfully analyzed the paper "Sharing of misinformation is habitual, not just lazy or biased" and completed all required tasks:

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution**
- The paper proposes a novel finding: that misinformation sharing is driven primarily by habitual behavior formed through platform reward structures, rather than individual deficits in reasoning or partisan bias.

**Identified Triples (7 entities):**

1. **Social media** (tool) - Uses: The primary platform where sharing behaviors are reinforced
2. **Misinformation** (concept) - Uses: The core phenomenon being studied
3. **Habit** (concept) - **Proposes**: The paper's main contribution showing habits drive sharing behavior
4. **Reward system** (concept) - Uses: The reward-based mechanisms on platforms that reinforce habits
5. **Political bias** (concept) - Uses: A commonly cited driver that the paper challenges
6. **Critical thinking** (concept) - Uses: Individual reasoning deficits being challenged as the primary cause
7. **Fake news** (concept) - Uses: The specific content type whose sharing patterns are analyzed

**Validation Status:** ✅ **PASSED**
- All Wikipedia URLs verified
- Paper type correctly set to "contribution"
- At least 1 "proposes" relation (required for contribution papers)
- At least 1 "uses" relation (required for all papers)

Sources:
- [Social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media)
- [Misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation)
- [Habit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habit)
- [Reward system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reward_system)
- [Political bias](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_bias)
- [Critical thinking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_thinking)
- [Fake news](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news)
